story.text: (Adds details, background)MEXICO CITY Jan 2 (Reuters) - The yield on Mexico's benchmark one-month Cetes, or T-bills, slipped by one basis point to 7.01 percent on Tuesday, despite the latest inflation data coming in higher than expected. Yields on three-month and six-month Cetes were unchanged at 7.17 percent and 7.20 percent at the central bank's weekly auction. Mexican consumer prices climbed a higher-than-expected 0.39 percent in the first half of December, making it less likely annual inflation will end the year under the central bank's target ceiling of 4 percent. However, confident the central bank has inflation under control, economists are debating when the bank might begin easing its key interest rate to boost economic growth. The yield on the 10-year bond fell to 7.43 percent on Tuesday from 7.56 percent the last time it was auctioned on Dec. 5.
story.title: update 1 - mexico 28 - day t - bills slips to 7 . 01 pct
